Title: The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany
Author: William L. Shirer
Takeaway: It only takes one bad actor. Someone as charismatic as Hitler will draw a following, especially if they are fanatical and preaching to a disenfranchised populace. It is not easy to find a solution to the trap that came from Hitler’s rise to power – appeasement certainly didn’t work but kneecapping probably kicked everything off to start with. I think you could argue Hitler was a strident utilitarian who believed the world would take on its best form if he was successful, value alignment is important.

Title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
Takeaway: Life can evolve steadily even if it makes everyone worse off (hunter-gatherers to agricultural revolution). Beliefs and trust are powerful concepts humans have control over.

Title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
Author: Daniel Kahneman
Takeaway: Much of human reasoning is described well by the paradigms of System 1 (fast, automatic) and System 2 (slow, effortful). Beware of the many biases and pitfalls that are inherent to the structure of the human mind.

Title: Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
Author: Jared Diamond
Takeaway: Grain and animals native to the Fertile Crescent led to agriculture, East-West axis of Eurasia led to disseminating ideas and rapid advancement of European culture and innovations. Germs are abundant in early agriculture societies, European settlers wiped out up to 95% (!) of North America natives with their germs.

Title: The Precipice: Existential Risk and the Future of Humanity
Author: Toby  Ord
Takeaway: Longtermism is very convincing, and urgent. All the risk of the next century comes from anthropogenic risk, with the bulk of that residing in the buckets of unaligned AI, engineered pandemics, and unknown anthropogenic risk. No doubt that working in this field is what I want to do.

Title: The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York
Author: Robert A. Caro
Takeaway: People that can command game theory power relations in real time can do extraordinary things. Be wary of incentives in politics.

Title: Destined for War: Can America and China Escape Thucydides’s Trap?
Author: Graham Allison
Takeaway: China is soon to be (if not already) the leading global power. 12/16 of the identified cases in which a rising power has displaced an established power have resulted in war. Probably the best way to flourish is to pull the strings and develop a symbiotic relationship, like US and UK.

Title: The Dictator's Handbook: Why Bad Behavior is Almost Always Good Politics
Author: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita, Alastair Smith
Takeaway: Well functioning democracy makes those in power accountable to the largest "winning coalition". Analyzing political leaders in the context of staying in power is probably a good starting place in almost all cases.

Title: Atlas Shrugged
Author: Ayn Rand
Takeaway: There is room for bringing about new philosophical systems, and writing a novel imagining Utopia is probably a good way to work through the details.

Title: Homo Deus: A History of Tomorrow
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
Takeaway: Myths are good at bringing people together and giving them common cause. Humanism is the current paradigm, but all bets are off if/when we cede the future to smarter beings.

Title: Artificial Intelligence: A Guide for Thinking Humans
Author: Melanie Mitchell
Takeaway: As of 2019 AI has a long way to go before it actually understands anything, and the abstractions it makes now are very different than those that humans make.

Title: Franny and Zooey
Author: J.D. Salinger
Takeaway: Just be, and respect people for who they are.

Title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
Author: Douglas Adams
Takeaway: What is the question? There is no requirement for meaning or purpose in anything.

Title: Exhalation
Author: Ted Chiang
Takeaway: It is both meaningless and unbelievably enticing to think about free will and its repercussions. And the 2nd law of thermodynamics is a real pain.

Title: Animal Farm
Author: George Orwell
Takeaway: Self interested agents mixed with deceit can lead to almost universally undesirable outcomes.

Title: Ethics in the Real World: 86 Brief Essays on Things that Matter
Author: Peter Singer
Takeaway: Medication to improve ethical reasoning could be possible, with interesting implications. Generally ethical problems can be worked through and brought to a solution after adopting a moral framework.

Title: The Stand
Author: Stephen King
Takeaway: Good and evil only exist relevant to moral frames. Contrasting worldviews must exist in society.

Title: Cat's Cradle
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Takeaway: A big danger brought about by new, powerful technology stems from accidental misuse, not necessarily intentionally bad actors.

Title: Brave New World
Author: Aldous Huxley
Takeaway: The state can change society’s Nash equilibrium profoundly, so that it does not agree with today’s values. What values should be preserved? Is a society full of people on Soma a utopia or a dystopia?

Title: Player Piano
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
Takeaway: Early automated society, where "managers and engineers" are still working but nobody else is needed, will be inequitable without thorough preparation

Title: The Life You Can Save: Acting Now to End World Poverty
Author: Peter Singer
Takeaway: A single person can, and is perhaps morally bound in a utilitarian framework, to make a large difference with the global poor.

Title: How to Measure Anything: Finding the Value of "Intangibles" in Business
Author: Douglas W. Hubbard
Takeaway: Put numbers on things, and carry confidence intervals. Identify what variable is driving the uncertainty and focus on refining that.

Title: Slaughterhouse-Five
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Takeaway: Make your life what you will, the universe is apathetic. So it goes.

Title: Merchants of Doubt: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming
Author: Naomi Oreskes
Takeaway: Entities will act according to their best interests, because they must. This does not stop at blurring lines in science, as the same group of people did for the effects of smoking, acid rain, DDT, ozone layer, and climate science. Always ask who has a stake in the outcome.

Title: Why We're Polarized
Author: Ezra Klein
Takeaway: People have evolved to be governed by their identities through in-group out-group association. Party politics has come to a head by cleanly sorting into two groups along many of the most important identities people have.

Title: Breakfast of Champions
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Takeaway: Maybe there is meaning in the chaos, maybe there isn’t, does it matter?

Title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Author: Philip K. Dick
Takeaway: We’ll likely never be able to tell if androids have consciousness, how do we possibly decide if they deserve moral standing?

Title: Gang Leader for a Day: A Rogue Sociologist Takes to the Streets
Author: Sudhir Venkatesh
Takeaway: Incentives are everywhere and shape just about everything, even (perhaps especially) the guidelines and rules we use to live our lives.

Title: The Art of Solitude
Author: Stephen Batchelor
Takeaway: Extended periods of solitude should be welcomed as a great way to achieve an open mind. And one day I need to try Ayahuasca.

Title: Good Economics for Hard Times: Better Answers to Our Biggest Problems
Author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo
Takeaway: Preferences are shaped by society, they aren’t magic. Trade and immigration are increasingly important as the world globalizes, and are hard problems.

Title: To Kill a Mockingbird
Author: Harper Lee
Takeaway: "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view"

Title: Doing Good Better: How Effective Altruism Can Help You Make a Difference
Author: William MacAskill
Takeaway: Effective charities are effective, and philanthropy is a science worth studying.

Title: The Kite Runner
Author: Khaled Hosseini
Takeaway: Love and friendship takes on many different shapes.

Title: Poor Economics: A Radical Rethinking of the Way to Fight Global Poverty
Author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo
Takeaway: Poverty is deeply seated in circumstance, and relief is a many-faceted problem.

Title: Stumbling on Happiness
Author: Daniel Todd Gilbert
Takeaway: We are not good at predicting what will make us happy. Imagination works constantly to fill in gaps and make guesses and is not to always be trusted.

Author: George Orwell
Takeaway: It is incredibly difficult to resist the 1984 future big brother state, or any well planned state regime probably, from within.

Title: The Sirens of Titan
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Takeaway: "A purpose of human life, no matter who is controlling it, is to love whoever is around to be loved."

Title: The Most Good You Can Do: How Effective Altruism Is Changing Ideas About Living Ethically
Author: Peter Singer
Takeaway: Effective Altruism is applied charity, and the utilitarian returns to charity take on a power law distribution.

Title: Ender's Game
Author: Orson Scott Card
Takeaway: It is either difficult or impossible to assign an objective "good guys vs bad guys", but so easy to fall into the thinking that your guys are the good guys.

Title: "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!": Adventures of a Curious Character
Author: Richard P. Feynman
Takeaway: Curiosity needs to be practiced consistently.

Title: Mister Fred
Author: Jill Pinkwater
Takeaway: Challenge kids and let them surprise you.

Title: Red Rising
Author: Pierce Brown
Takeaway: Hierarchical societies don’t seem like a good idea. In a society with stratification, all people will bring valuable and varied insight to governing given the opportunity.

Title: Foundation
Author: Isaac Asimov
Takeaway: Human nature is near constant, and, if the environment is set appropriately, future events can be forecasted from the known initial conditions.

Title: The Giver
Author: Lois Lowry
Takeaway: We only live in the world we sense.

Title: The Catcher in the Rye
Author: J.D. Salinger
Takeaway: We grow up, all we can do is appreciate the path.

Title: Impro: Improvisation and the Theatre
Author: Keith Johnstone
Takeaway: Social interaction can be entirely practiced and improved upon. I really don’t want to but I should take improv classes.

Title: Recursion
Author: Blake Crouch
Takeaway: There is nothing "real" about the past, collective memories are all that remain.

Title: Siddhartha
Author: Hermann Hesse
Takeaway: The combination of experiences alone can lead to enlightenment.

Title: Lord of the Flies
Author: William Golding
Takeaway: Friendly, democratic civilization, as opposed to chaos and rule by power, is not to be taken for granted.

Title: How to Read a Book: The Classic Guide to Intelligent Reading
Author: Mortimer J. Adler
Takeaway: Read books with purpose, and ideally in stages.

Title: A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines
Author: Janna Levin
Takeaway: Godel and Turing demonstrate how blurred the line between minds and computers can be, and what incredible variety minds can show.

Title: The Way of Kings
Author: Brandon Sanderson
Takeaway: It can be really hard to see life through a different point of view, and doing so may have profound impacts on what is right and wrong.

Title: Dune
Author: Frank Herbert
Takeaway: "When religion and politics travel in the same cart, the riders believe nothing can stand in their way. Their movements become headlong - faster and faster and faster. They put aside all thoughts of obstacles and forget the precipice does not show itself to the man in a blind rush until it's too late."

Title: The Old Man and the Sea
Author: Ernest Hemingway
Takeaway: Seeing things through for the sake of seeing things through can be simultaneously honorable and foolish.

Title: Mother Night
Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Takeaway: "We are what we pretend to be, so we must be careful about what we pretend to be"

Title: The Martian
Author: Andy Weir
Takeaway: Be resourceful, learn to make the best with what you have.

Title: The Count of Monte Cristo
Author: Alexandre Dumas
Takeaway: Revenge is not worthwhile.

Title: The Name of the Wind
Author: Patrick Rothfuss
Takeaway: Storytelling is a good skill to have and should be practiced.

Title: The Gunslinger
Author: Stephen King
Takeaway: Relentless pursuit of goals is a goal itself.

Title: My Brilliant Friend
Author: Elena Ferrante
Takeaway: We are unbelievably fortunate to grow up in rich western society. The violence and family politics present in this poor Italian city is not even imaginable, and maybe that gives us hope for economic growth to usher in an even less violent future.

Title: Where the Crawdads Sing
Author: Delia Owens
Takeaway: Spending all your time immersed and observant in an environment leads to deep understanding.

Title: Fight Club
Author: Chuck Palahniuk
Takeaway: Chaos has a place, but things can get out of control quickly.

Title: The Windup Girl
Author: Paolo Bacigalupi
Takeaway: "Politics is ugly. Never doubt what small men will do for great power."

Title: Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality
Author: Eliezer Yudkowsky
Takeaway: Statistics and experimentation can be applied to everyday things.

Title: A Confederacy of Dunces
Author: John Kennedy Toole
Takeaway: Empty whining about things doesn’t help anything.

Title: The Metamorphosis
Author: Franz Kafka
Takeaway: Making people give up their life to help you is pretty selfish.

Title: Blithe Tomato
Author: Mike Madison
Takeaway: Learn to find the beauty in simple things.
